metadata.case_name: Indore Iron and Steel Registered Stock-holders Association Private Ltd. v. State of Madhya Bharat

facts.text: The appellant is a registered Association whose constituent members carry on business in fabricated iron and steel material including iron sheets plain or corrugated, bars, rods, light and heavy structurals, nails, joints, wire nails and all kinds and varieties of wires and pipes at Indore and Ratlam.

State of Madhya Bharat by Act No. 30 of 1950 imposed sales tax on sales of specified goods with effect from May 1, 1950. Commissioner of Sales Tax and Sales Tax Officer, Indore appointed for assessment and recovery.
Section 3 of the Act is the charging section. Section 4(2) provides no tax on sale of goods in Sch. 1 second column on conditions in third column. Iron and steel is item 39 in Sch. 1.
Section 5 prescribes rate of tax notified by Government, not less than 1/2% or more than 6.25%. Section 4(3) and 5(2) authorize Government to modify Sch. 1 and notify goods and point of sale.

Notification issued on May 22, 1950 under s.5(2) specifying articles taxed, stage and rate. Item 27: goods manufactured from metals except gold and silver or from more than one metal except circles and sheets of copper, brass, aluminium; tax by producer or importer at 3.2%.
Article 286(3) of Constitution came into force. Parliament by Act 52 of 1952 s.2 declared goods in Sch. essential for life of community, item 14: iron and steel, effective August 9, 1952.

State issued two notifications on October 24, 1953: first no tax on iron and steel (item 39); second item 9: every kind of metal excluding iron, steel, gold, silver and goods prepared from any metal other than gold and silver, utensils, wires etc. excluding circles and sheets of copper, brass, aluminium.
Appellant's constituent members' articles covered by item 9 notification, liable to sales tax.
Appellant wrote to Sales Tax Officer claiming exemption; plea rejected, members called to pay tax on individual turnover.
Appellant filed writ petitions under Art. 226 in High Court of Madhya Bharat at Indore: Petition No. 26 of 1954 for 1953-54 and No. 48 of 1955 for 1954-55, challenging assessment orders.
High Court upheld respondents' plea, rejected appellant's contentions, dismissed writs.
Present appeals Nos. 509 and 510 of 1960 by special leave against High Court orders.

legal_issues.text: Whether words 'iron and steel' in s.2 of Act 52 of 1952 include articles made exclusively of iron and steel in which steel merchants normally trade, as understood in commercial sense.
Whether the impugned notification of October 24, 1953 contravenes Art. 286(3) of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 2 of Act 52/1952 covers iron and steel in commercial sense, not narrow dictionary meaning; includes articles exclusively made from iron and steel where identity not lost, i.e., all articles made exclusively of iron and steel in which steel merchants normally trade.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 286(3); s.2 Act 52/1952; legislative history including Iron and Steel Control Order 1941, Essential Supplies Act 1946 s.2(a)(vii), Essential Commodities Act 1955 s.2(a)(vi)

petitioner_arguments.text: Object of Art. 286(3) to safeguard consumer interest in essential articles requires broad construction of iron and steel.

respondent_arguments.text: Notification of October 24, 1953 valid; item 27 in May 22, 1950 list brings articles within Sales Tax Act; petitioners not entitled to writ.
Words iron and steel in Entry 14 Sch. to Act 52/1952 do not include articles made of iron and steel.

court_reasoning.text: Even assuming broad commercial interpretation of 'iron and steel' covers appellant's commodities, impugned notification does not contravene Art. 286(3) because Madhya Bharat Act 30/1950 pre-dates parliamentary declaration (Aug 9, 1952). Art. 286(3) applies only to post-Constitution State laws imposing tax on already declared essential goods without President's assent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Three conditions for Art. 286(3): (1) post-Constitution State law; (2) imposes tax on goods already declared essential by Parliament; (3) not reserved for President's assent. Act 30/1950 satisfies (1) but not (2) as declaration post-dates Act.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 286(3) not retrospective; declaration prospective. Section 3 of Act 52/1952 confirms affects laws made after its commencement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pre-existing laws authorizing tax on commodities later declared essential not invalidated.

court_reasoning.text: High Court correctly held notifications outside purview of Art. 286(3) and s.3 Act 52/1952.

holdings.text: Impugned notifications valid and do not contravene Art. 286(3); appeals fail as appellant must succeed on both points but fails on whether notification contravenes Art. 286(3).

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upholding the High Court's dismissal of writ petitions. Held that even assuming 'iron and steel' includes fabricated articles, the notifications under pre-1952 Act do not contravene Art. 286(3) as it applies prospectively to laws post-dating the declaration.

key_quotes.text: Article 286(3) contemplates that if in the face of an existing parliamentary declaration about the essential character of a commodity the Legislature of a State purports to impose or authorise the imposition of a tax on such commodity the enactment would be invalid unless reserved for President and assented.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains conditions precedent for invoking Art. 286(3)

key_quotes.text: The declaration made by the Act was intended to be prospective in operation and it would affect laws made after the commencement of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
